metadata.titleEn: Genome Assembly of Alpine Species Salix Brachista on the Tibetan Plateau (2019)
metadata.description:
This dataset is collected from the paper: Chen, J.*#, Huang, Y.*#, Brachi, B.*#, Yun, Q.*#, Zhang, W., Lu, W., Li, H., Li, W., Sun, X., Wang, G., He, J., Zhou, Z., Chen, K., Ji, Y., Shi, M., Sun, W., Yang, Y.*, Zhang, R.#, Abbott, R. J.*, & Sun, H.* (2019). Genome-wide analysis of Cushion willow provides insights into alpine plant divergence in a biodiversity hotspot. Nature Communications, 10(1), 5230. doi:10.1038/s41467-019-13128-y. 
This data contains the genome assembly of alpine species Salix brachista on the Tibetan Plateau, it contains DNA, RNA, Protein files in Fasta format and the annotation file in gff format.
Assembly Level: Draft genome in chromosome level
Genome Representation: Full Genome
Reference Genome: yes
Assembly method: SMARTdenovo 1.0; CANU 1.3
Sequencing & coverage: PacBio 125.0; Illumina Hiseq X Ten 43.0; Oxford Nanopore Technologies 74.0
Statistics of Genome Assembly:
Genome size (bp): 339,587,529
GC content: 34.15%
Chromosomes sequence No.: 19
Organellas sequence No.: 2
Genome sequence No.: 30
Maximum genome sequence length (bp): 39,688,537
Minimum genome sequence length (bp): 57,080
Average genome sequence length (bp): 11,319,584
Genome sequence N50 (bp): 17,922,059
Genome sequence N90 (bp): 13,388,179
Annotation of Whole Genome Assembly:
Protein：30,209
tRNA：784
rRNA：118
ncRNA：671
Please see attachments for more details of annotation.
The tables in the Supplementary Information of this article can also be found in this dataset. The table list is represented in attachments.
The accession no. of genome assembly is GWHAAZH00000000 (https://bigd.big.ac.cn/gwh/Assembly/663/show).
metadata.instructions:
The data in Supplementary Information is named according to the paper, it can be viewed and edited by Excel software of Microsoft Office;
The data of genome assembly can be viewed by notepad software.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used for assembling the genome of an alpine plant species at the chromosome level?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used for assembling the genome of an alpine plant species at the chromosome level is the combination of sequencing technologies such as PacBio with a depth of 125×, Illumina Hiseq X Ten with a depth of 43×, and Oxford Nanopore Technologies with a depth of 74×. The assembly was performed using methods like SMARTdenovo 1.0 and CANU 1.3, achieving a chromosome-level assembly for the genome of Cushion willow.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of genome assembly methods used for alpine plants in high-altitude environments?
Feature Specification.Answer: SMARTdenovo 1.0, CANU 1.3, chromosome-level assembly, whole genome coverage, PacBio depth of 125×, Illumina Hiseq X Ten 43×, Oxford Nanopore Technologies 74×, genome size 339,587,529 bp, 19 chromosomes, GC content 34.15%

Quantification.Question: What is the total sequencing depth used in the genome assembly of Cushion willow from the Tibetan Plateau?

Comparison.Question: How do the sequencing depths and technologies used in genome assembly of alpine plants compare with those used in other high-altitude plant genome projects?
Comparison.Answer: The genome assembly of alpine plants on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau uses sequencing technologies such as PacBio with a depth of 125×, Illumina Hiseq X Ten with a depth of 43×, and Oxford Nanopore Technologies with a depth of 74×. These methods and depths may vary in other high-altitude plant genome projects, depending on the specific requirements of the project and the resources available, potentially affecting the assembly quality and completeness.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the selection of specific sequencing methods and depth for genome assembly in alpine plant genomics?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The selection of sequencing methods and depth in alpine plant genomics is influenced by the need for high-quality, comprehensive data to cover the entire genome. In this case, multiple sequencing technologies, including PacBio, Illumina Hiseq X Ten, and Oxford Nanopore Technologies, were chosen to achieve a combined sequencing depth of 125×, 43×, and 74× respectively. This multi-platform approach allows researchers to take advantage of the strengths of each technology, such as high accuracy, long reads, and coverage, to ensure a robust and complete genome assembly, especially at the chromosome level. The specific choices are likely influenced by the complexity of the genome, the GC content, and the need for accurate assembly and annotation of chromosome-level sequences.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of assembling a genomic dataset at the chromosome level for alpine plants in biodiversity hotspots?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to provide insights into the genetic divergence of alpine plants, particularly the Cushion willow, in biodiversity hotspots like the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau. This high-resolution genomic data helps in understanding plant adaptation and evolution in extreme environments.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used to assemble a genome at the chromosome level, and what specific sequencing technologies and coverage depths are involved in such a process?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The genome assembly at the chromosome level involves using assembly methods such as SMARTdenovo 1.0 and CANU 1.3. The specific sequencing technologies used include PacBio with a coverage depth of 125×, Illumina Hiseq X Ten with 43×, and Oxford Nanopore Technologies with 74×.
